editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. div.p: Quod non dant proceres, dabit histrio.
London: printed by Robert Raworth, for Nicholas Vavasour; and are to be sold at his shop in the inner temple, near the church-door. 1636.

lg.l: Thus from the poet, I am bid to say;
He knows what judges sit to doom each play,
(The overcurious critic, or the wise)
The one with squint; tother with sun-like eyes,
Shoots through each scene; the one cries all things down
Tother, hides strangers faults, close as his own:
'Las! Those that out of custom come to jeer,
(Sung the full choir of the nine muses here)
So carping, — not from wit, but apish spite,
And feathered ignorance, — thus! O poet does slight.
'Tis not a gay suit, or distorted face,
Can beat his merit off, — which has won grace
In the full theater; — nor can now fear
The teeth of any snaky whisperer;
But to the white, and sweet unclowded brow,
(The heaven where true worth moves) our poet does bow:
Patrons of arts, and pilots to the stage,
Who guide it (Through all tempests) from the rage
Of envious whirlwinds, — o, do you but steer
His muse, this day; and bring her toth' wished shore,
You are those Delphic powers whom she'll adore.

list.item: Tibaldo Neri, lover of Dariene L. Vanni's wife.

div.head: The wonder of a kingdom.
Actus primus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Duke of Florence, prince of Pisae, Nicoletto Vanni, Trebatio his son, Mutio, Philippo, Tornelli, gallants, Tibaeldo Neri, Alphonsina his sister, Daeriene old Vanny's wife, Cargo a servingman.

sp.l: We surfeit here on pleasures: seas nor land
Cannot invite us to a feast more glorious,
Than this day we have sat at: my lord Vanni,
You have an excellent seat here; 'tis a building
May entertain a Caesar: but you and I
Should rather talk of tombs, than palaces,
Let's leave all to our heirs, for we are old.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Old! hem? all heart of brass, sound as a bell,
Old? why, I'll tell your graces; I have gone
But half the bridge o'er yet; there lies before me
As much as I have passed, and I'll go it all.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Mad Vanni still.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Old oaks do not easily fall:
December's cold hand combs my head and beard,
But may swims in my blood; and he that walks
Without his wooden third leg, is never old.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What is your age my lord?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Age, what call you age?
I have lived some half a day, some half an hour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A tree of threescore-years growth; nothing.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: A mere slip, you have kept good diet my lord.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Let whores keep diet,
Tibaldo ne'er; never did rivers run
In wilder, madder streams, than I have done,
I'll drink as hard yet as an Englishman,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And they are now best drinkers.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: They put down the Dutchmen clean,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I'll yet upon a wager hit any fencer's button,

sp.speaker: Car,
sp.l: Some of 'em ha' no buttons to their doublets.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Then knave I'll hit his flesh, and hit your cocks -
If you cross mine once more. (Comb

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Nay be not angry.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I have my passes: and my passadoes,
My longes, my stoccadoes, imbrocadoes,
And all my pimtoes, and pimtillioes
Here at my finger's ends.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By my faith 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Old why; I never took physic, nor ever will,
I'll trust none that has art and leave to kill:
Now for that chopping herb of hell tobacco;
The idle-man's-devil, and the drunkard's-whore,
I never meddled with her, my smoke goes,
Out at my kitchen chimney, not my nose.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And some lords have no chimneys but their noses.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Tobacco-shops show like prisons in hell;
Hot, smoky, stinking, and I hate the smell.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Who'd think that in a coal of ashy white,
Such fire were glowing?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: May not a snuff give light?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You see it does in him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: A withered-tree, doth oft bear branches.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: What think you then of me sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Troth my lord as of a horse, vilely, if he can
Neither wehee, nor wagtail.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The lady Alphonsina Neri, has given it you my lord.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: The time may come I may give it her too.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.l: I doubt lord Vanni she will crack no nuts,
With such a tough shell, as is yours and mine,
But leaving this, let's see you pray, at court,

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Your wife, and your fair daughter,
One of the stars of Florence with your son
Heir to your worth and honours, Trebatio Vanni.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: I shall attend your grace.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The holy knot,
Hymen shall shortly tie, and in fair bands,
Unite Florence and Pisa by the hands,
Or Fiametta and this Pisa Duke
(Our noble son in law) and at this day,
Pray be not absent.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: We shall your will obey,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: We hear there is a gallant that outvies
Us, and our court for bravery, and expense,
For royal feasts, triumphs and revellings.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: He's my near kinsman, mine own brother's son,
Who desperately a prodigal race doth run,
And for this riotous humour, he has the byname,
Signior Torrenti, a swift headlong stream.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But there's another lays on more than he.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Old Jacomo? open handed charity,
Sits ever at his gates to welcome guests,
He makes no bonfires, as my riotous kinsman,
And yet his chimneys cast out braver smoke,
The bellows which he blows with are good deeds,
The rich he smiles upon, the poor he feeds.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: These gallants we'll be feasted by, and feast
Fame's praises of 'em, shall make us their guest,
Mean time we'll hence

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have news to tell your lordship, signior Angelo (Of the Locti family is banished.

sp.speaker: Dari.
sp.l: How banished? alas poor Angelo Lotti.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Why must he go from Florence?

sp.speaker: Cargo.
sp.l: Because he can stay there no longer.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: To what end is he driven from the city?

sp.speaker: Cargo.
sp.l: To the end he should go into some other my lord.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Hoida.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I hope this is news sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: What speak the people of him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As bells ring; some out, some in, all jangle, they say he has dealt with the Genoese against the state: but whether with the men, or the women; 'tis to be stood upon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Away sir knave and fool.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sir knave, a new word: fools, and knaves sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: This muttering long ago flew to mine ear,
The Genoese is but a line thrown out,
But Fiametta's love, the net that chokes him.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.l: He's worthy of her equal,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Peace foolish boy,
At these state bonfires (Whose flames reach so high)
To stand aloof, is safer than too nigh.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Why brother, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I'm ill, exceeding ill.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: That's not well.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Sure I did surfeit at lord Vanny's.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Surfeit? you eat some meat against your stomach.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: No, but I had a stomach to one dish, and the not tasting it, makes me sick at heart.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Was it fish or flesh?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Flesh sure, if I hit the mark right.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Is't not the missing of a mark (Which you long to hit)
Makes you draw sighs in stead of arrows?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Would I had been a thousand leagues from thence,
When I sat down at's table or been partner
With Angelo Lotti in his banishment;
Oh! sister Alphonsina, there I drank
My bane the strongest poison that e'er man
Drew from a lady's eye, now swelling in me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: By casting of thy water thy, I guess thou wouldst
Have a medicine for the green sickness.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: 'Tis a green wound indeed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Tent it, tent it, and keep it from rankling, you are
Over head and ears in love.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am and with such mortal arrows pierced
I shall fall down —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: There's no hurt in that.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: And die unless he her pity
Send me a quick and sweet recovery.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And faith what doctress is she must call you patient?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Fair Dariene, the lord Vanny's wife —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: How! Dariene? can no feather fit you but the broach in an
Old man's hat? were there so many dainty dishes
To fill your belly, and must you needs long for that dish
The master of the house sets up for his own tooth.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Could love be like a subject, tied to laws,
Then might you speak this language.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Love? A disease as common with young-gallants as
Swaggering and drinking tobacco, there's not one
Of they all but will today lie drawing on for a
Woman, as if they were puffing and blowing at a straight boot,
And tomorrow be ready to knock at death's door,
But I would fain see one of you enter and set in
His staff.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You shall see me then do so.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I shall look so old first, I shall be taken for thy grandam; come, come 'tis but a worm between the skin and the flesh, and to be taken out with the point of a waiting-woman's needle, as well as a great countesses.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: If this be all the comfort you will lend me,
Would you might leave me —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Leave thee in sickness? I had more need give thee a caudle; and thrust thy addle-head into a nightcap, for look you brother —

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Even what you will must out

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: If what you will might so too, then would you be in
Tune: I warrant, if the sucket stood here before
Thee, thy stomach would go against it.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Yes sure my stomach would go against it:
'Tis only that which breeds in me despair.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Despair for a woman? they hang about men's
Necks in some places thicker than hope upon poles.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Her walls of chastity cannot be beaten down.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Walls of chastity? walls of wafer-cakes, I have
Known a woman carry a featherbed, and a man in't
In her mind, when in the street she cast up the white of
Her eye like a Puritan.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Sister you do but stretch me on the rack
And with a laughing cheek increase my pain,
Be rather pitiful and ease my torments
By teaching me how in this dreadful storm,
I may escape shipwreck and attain that shore
Where I may live, here else I'm sure to die.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Well brother, since you will needs sail by such a
Star as I shall point out, look you here it is; if she were
Your feather-makers, tailors or barber's wife,
Bait a hook with gold, and with it —

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I do conjure you by that noble blood
Which makes me call you sister, cease to pour
Poison into a wound, so near my heart,
And if to cure loves-pains there be an art.
Woman methinks should know it cause she breeds it,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: That cunning woman you take me to be, and because
I see you dissemble not, here's my medicine.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I shall for ever thank you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: First send for your barber.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: For heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Your barber shall not come to rob you of your beard,
I'll deal in no concealments —

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Oh! fie, fie, fie —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: But let him by rubbing of you quicken
Your spirits.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: So so.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Then whistle your goldfinches (Your gallants) to your fist.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You're mad, you're mad.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Into a tavern, drink stiff, swear stiff; have your music, and your brace, dance, and whiff tobacco,
sp.l: Till all smoke again, and split sir.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You split my very heart in pieces.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: And do thus, but till the Moor cuts off her horns; laugh in the day, and sleep in the night: and this wenching fire will be burned out of you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Away, away, cruel you are to kill,
When to give life, you have both power and skill.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Alas, poor brother now I pity thee and would do
Any thing to help thee to thy longing, but that a
Gap must be broken, in another man's hedge to rob
His orchard, within there Luca Angelo, give him
Music:
Music has helped some madmen, let it then
Charm him, love makes fools of the wisest men.
sp.stage: Enter at one door, Angelo Lotti, and Baptista, at the other, Piero, and Jaspero.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Yonder's that villain, keep off Jaspero:
This prey I'll cease.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Be more advised sir.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: At whose life shoot you?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: At that slaves there.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Slave? I know you for the Duke's son, but I know no cause of quarrel, or this base reproach.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Thou art a villain.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Wherein?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: And by witchcraft,
Had stole my sister Fiametta's heart,
Forcing her leave a prince his bed for thine.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: If for her love you come to kill me; here
sp.p: I'll point you to a door where you may enter and fetch out a loathed life.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Jaspero.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: O my lord.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let him come, I owe her all;
And that debt will I pay her gladly.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Dear sir hear him —

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: But if on any other fire of rage;
You thirst to drink my blood, here I defy
you, and your malice; and return the villain
Into your throat.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: So brave sir.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I charge you in the Duke's name, keep the peace;
Beat down their weapons, knock 'em down Cargo.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have a justice's warrant to apprehend your weapons,
Therefore I charge you deliver.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: O my lord: make a fray in an open street? 'tis to
Make a bonfire to draw children and fools
Together; signior Angelo, pray be wise, and begone.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I do but guard my life (My lord) from danger.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Sir, you do exercise your violence;
Upon a man, stabbed to the heart with wounds;
You see him sinking, and you set your foot
Upon his head, to kill him with two deaths;
Trample not thus on a poor banished man.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: If he be banished, why dwells he ith' house, whose
Tiles are pulled down over his head? You must hunt
No more in this park of Florence; why then
Do you lie sneaking here, to steal venison?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My lords, I take my last leave of you all;
Of love, and fortunes —

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Lower thou canst not fall.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: Trust me, my lord, this Lotti is a man,
(Setting aside his rivalship in love,
For which you hate him) so abundant rich
In all the virtues of a gentleman,
That had you read their file, as I have done,
You would not only fall in love with him,
And hold him worthy of a Princess bed,
But grieve, that for a woman, such a man
Should so much suffer; in being so put down,
Never to rise again.

sp.speaker: Nicol.
sp.l: A terrible case, I'd not be in't for all Florence.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Troth dear friend,
The praises which have crowned him with thy judgement,
Make me to cast on him an open eye,
which was before shut, and I pity him.
I never heard amongst all your Roman spirits.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: That any held so bravely up his head,
In such a sea of troubles (That come rolling
One on another's neck) as Lotti doth,
He puts the spite of fortune to disgrace,
And makes her, when she frowns worst, turn her face.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: No more: I love him; and for all the dukedom,
Would not have cut so noble a spreading vine,
To draw from it one drop of blood; lord Vanni,
I thank you that you cured our wounded peace,
So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: A good health to you both.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: You play the constable wisely.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: And I his beadle, I hope as wisely.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: The constable wisely; Cargo he calls me fool by craft,
But let 'em pass.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: As gentlemen do by creditors (Muffled)

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.p: I have another case to handle: thou knowest the donna Alphonsina, of the Neri family.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: The little paraquito that was here when the Duke
Was feasted, she had quicksilver in her mouth, for
Her tongue, like a bride the first night, never lay still.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: The same aspenleaf, the same; is't not a galley for
The great Turk to be rowed in?

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: I think my lord, in calm weather, she may set upon
A galleass big as your lordship.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Commend me to this Angelica.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: Angelica-water is good for a cold stomach.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I am all fire.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: She's a cooler.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Would 'twere come to that.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: A small thing does it my lord; in the time a
Flemming drinks a flap-dragon.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.p: Give her this paper, and this; in the one she may know my mind, in the other, feel me: this a letter, this a jewel:
sp.l: Tell her, I kiss the little white nail of her little white
Finger, of her more little white hand, of her most
Little white body.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: Her tell-tale, for all this will I be.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.p: Thou hast been my weaver's shuttle to run betwixt me and my stuffs of procreandi causa.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: A suit of stand-farther-off, had been better sometimes.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: No Cargo, I have still the lapis mirabilis; be thou close —

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: As my lady's chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Away then, nay quick knave, thou rackest me.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: I go to stretch you to your full length.
sp.stage: Enter Jocomo Gentili, in a suit of grey, velvet-gown, cap, chain, steward, and serving-men, Mutio, Philippo, Tornelli Montinello.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Happy be your arrival, noble friends;
You are the first, that like to doves repair
To my new building; you are my firstborn guests,
My eldest sons of hospitality;
Here's to my hearty welcomes.

sp.speaker: Mutio.
sp.l: Worthy lord,
In one word, and the word of one, for all,
Our thanks are as your welcomes, infinite.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Rome in her ancient pride, never raised up
A work of greater wonder, than this building.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis finished, and the cost stands on no score,
None can for want of payment, at my door,
Curse my foundation, praying the roof may fall
On the proud builder's' head, seeing the smoke go
Out of those chimneys, for whose bricks I owe.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: To erect a frame so glorious, large, and high,
Would draw a very sea of silver dry.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: My lord Jocomo Gentili, pray tell us,
How much money have you buried under this kingly building?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pray call it not so:
The humble shrub, no cedar here shall grow;
You see three hundred Doric pillars stand
About one square, three hundred noble friends
Laid (In their loves) at raising of those columns,
A piece of gold under each pedestal,
With his name graved upon the bottom stone,
Except that cost, all other was mine own;
see here, each day's expenses are so great,
They make a volume, for in this appears,
It was no task of weeks, or months, but years:
I trust my steward only with the key,
Which keeps that secret; here's arithmetic
For churls to cast up, there's the root of all;
If you have skill in numbers, number that.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Good Mr. steward read it.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: All the charge
In the gross sum, amounteth to —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: To what?
Thou vain vainglorious fool, go burn that book,
No herald needs to blazon charity's arms;
Go burn it presently.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: Burn it?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Away,
I launch not forth a ship, with drums and guns,
And trumpets, to proclaim my gallantry;
He that will read the wasting of my gold,
Shall find it writ in ashes, which the wind
Will scatter ere he spends it; another day,
The wheel may turn, and I that built thus high,
May by the storms of want, be driven to dwell
In a thatched cottage; rancour shall not then
Spit poison at me, pinning on my back
This card; he that spent thus much, now does lack.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Why to your house add you so many gates?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My gates fill up the number of seven days,
At which, of guests, seven several sorts I'll welcome:
On Monday, knights whose fortunes are sunk low;
On Tuesday, those that all their life-long read
The huge voluminous wonders of the deep,
Seamen (I mean) and so on other days,
Others shall take their turns.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why have you then built twelve such vast rooms.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: For the years twelve moons;
In each of which, twelve tables shall be spread;
At them, such whom the world scorns, shall be fed,
The windows of my building, which each morn,
Are porters, to let in man's comfort (Light)
are numbered just three hundred sixty five,
And in so many days the sun does drive
His chariot stuck with beams of burnished gold,
My alms shall such diurnal progress make
As does the sun in his bright-zodiack.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: You differ from the guise of other lands,
Where lords lay all their livings on the rack,
Not spending it in bread, but on the back.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Such lords eat men, but men shall eat up me,
My uncle the lord abbot had a soul
Subtle and quick, and searching as the fire,
By magic-stayers he went as deep as hell,
And if in devil's possession gold be kept,
He brought some sure from thence, 'tis hid in caves
Known (Save to me) to none, and like a spring
The more 'tis drawn, the more it still doth rise,
The more my heap wastes, more it multiplies.
Now whether (As most richmen do) he pawned
His soul for that dear purchase none can tell,
But by his bedside when he saw death stand
Fetching a deep groan, me he catch't-by'th hand
Called me his heir, and charged me well to spend
What he had got ill, deal (Quoth he) a dole
Which round (With good men's prayers) may guard my soul
Now at her setting forth: let none feel want
That knock but at thy gates: do wrong to none,
And what request to thee so ear is made,
If honest, see it never be denied.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And you'll perform all this?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Fair and upright,
As are the strict vows of an anchorite:
A benefit given by a niggard's hand
Is stale and gravelly bread, the hunger-starved
Takes it, but cannot eat it; I'll give none such.
Who with free heart shakes out but crumbs, gives much.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: In such a ship of worldly cares my lord
As you must sail now in, you'll need more pilots
Than your own self to sit and steer the helm.
You might do therefore well to take a wife;

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A wife? when I shall have one hand in heaven,
To write my happiness in leaves of stars;
A wife would pluck me by the other down:
This bark hath thus long sailed about the world,
My soul the pilot, and yet never listened
To such a mermaid's song: a wife, o fetters,
To man's blessed liberty! All this world's a prison,
Heaven the high wall about it, sin the jailer,
But the iron-shackles weighing down our heels,
Are only women, those light angels turn us,
To fleshly devils, I that sex admire,
But never will sit near their wanton fire.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Who then shall reap the golden corn you sow?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: 'Tis half a curse to them, that build, and spare, and hoard up wealth, yet cannot name an heir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My heirs shall be poor children fed on alms,
Soldiers that want limbs, scholars poor and scorned.
And these will be a sure inheritance;
Not to decay: manors and towns will fall,
Lordships and parks, pastures and woods be sold;
But this land still continues to the lord:
No subtle tricks of law, can me beguile of this.
But of the beggars-dish, I shall drink healths
To last for ever; whilst I live, my roof
Shall cover naked wretches; when I die,
'Tis dedicated to st. charity.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: The Duke informed, what trees of goodness grow,
Here of your planting, in true love to your virtues;
Sent us to give you thanks, for crowning Florence,
With fame of such a subject, and entreats you
(Until he come himself) to accept this token,
Of his fair wishes towards you.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Pray return
My duty to the Duke, tell him I value his love
Beyond all jewels in the world.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Has vowed ere long to be your visitant.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He shall be welcome when he comes, that's all;
not to a palace, but my hospital.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We'll leave your lordship.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My best thoughts go with you:
My steward?
sp.stage: Enter steward, and a foolish gentleman.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is the book fired?

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: As you commanded sir, I saw it burned.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Keep safe that jewel, and leave me; letters! from whom?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Signior Jeronimo Guydanes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O sir, I know the business: yes, yes, 'tis the same;
Cuidanes lives amongst my bosom friends:
He writes to have me entertain you sir.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: That's the bough, my bolt flies at, my lord.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What qualities are you furnished with?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: My education has been like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Have you any skill in song, or instrument?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: As a gentleman should have, I know all, but play on none: I am no barber.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Barber! no sir, I think it; are you a linguist?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: As a gentleman ought to be, one tongue serves one head;
I am no pedlar, to travel countries.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What skill ha'you in horsemanship?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: As other gentlemen have, I ha' rid some beasts in my time.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Can you write and read then?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: As most of your gentlemen do, my band has been
Taken with my mark at it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I see you are a dealer, give me thy hand, I'll entertain thee howsoever, because in thee I keep half a score gentlemen; thy name.

sp.speaker: Buz
sp.l: A sinius Buzardo — —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I entertain thee, good Buzardo.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Thanks sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This fellow's a stark fool, or too wise,
The trial will be with what wing he flies.

div.head: Actus secundus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Tibaldo sick in his chair, Alphonsina, Mutio, Philippo, Tornelli, Montivello.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: In laws of courtesy, we are bound sweet lady,
(Being thus nigh) to see you and your brother,
Our noble friend, though the Duke had not sent.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Thanks worthy sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Signior Tibaldo hath desire to sleep.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Then leave him, company offends the sick.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Our humblest duty to my lord the Duke;
If in my brother's name, and mine, you tender
For this his noble love, we both shall rest
Highly indebted to you all.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Sweet madam,
You shall command our lives to work your good.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Signior, your love.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: All at your service madam.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: A quick, and good health to your noble brother.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And all fair fortunes doubled on yourself.
sp.p: So: methinks a lady had more need have a new pair of lips, than a new pair of gloves, for though they were both of one skin, yet one would wear out sooner than the other; I think these courtiers have all offices in the spicery, and taking my lips for sweetmeats, are as saucy with 'em, as if they were fees; I wonder Tibaldo thou canst fit still, and not come in for a share; if old Vanni's wife had been here, all the parts about you had moved.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Thou think'st I lie in, here's such a gossipping, as if 'twere a childbed chamber.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: So 'tis, for I'll swear, all this stir is about having a woman brought to bed; marry I doubt it must be a man's lying in.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I would thy tongue were a man then, to lie.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I had rather it were a woman, to tell truth.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Good sister Alphonsina, you still play
the bad physician, I am all on fire,
And you to quench me, pour on scoops of oil;
I feel ten thousand plummets at my heart,
Yet you cry, lay on more and are more cruel
Than all my tortures.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Sadness, I pity thee,
And will to do thee service, venture life,
Mine honour being kept spotless.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Gentle sister,
The easiest thing ith' world to beg, I crave,
And the poorest alms to give.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: But ask and have.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: A friendly counsel, lo that's all.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: 'Tis yours.
Be ruled by me then; in an ashy sheet,
Cover these glowing embers of desire.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Embers? I would you telled 'em, 'tis a fire —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Come, and set hand to paper, I'll indite.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: And she'll condemn me; no, I will not write.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Then prithee take this physic; be not the sea, to drink strange rivers up, yet still be dry; be like a noble stream, covet to run betwixt fair banks, which thou mayest call thine own, and let those banks be some fair ladies arms, fit for thy youth, and birth.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Against your charms,
Witch, thus I stop mine ears.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I'll hollow them: this deer runs in my lord's park,
And if you steal it, look to have bloodhounds scent you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Yes, you shall find venison-sauce dearer than other flesh.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: No, no, none else must, none shall, none can,
My hunger feed but this; down will I dive,
And fetch this pearl, or ne'er come up alive —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Are all my warm caudles come to this? now I see thou'rt too far gone, this lady hath overspent thee therefore settle thine estate, pluck up a good heart, and I'll pen thy will.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: O fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Bequeath thy kisses to some tailor, that hunts out weddings every Sunday; item, thy sighs to a noise of fiddlers ill paid, thy paleness to a fencer fighting at sharp, thy want of stomach to one of the Duke's guard.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I beg it at thy hands, that being a woman, thou'lt make a wonder.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Hold thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: It's an instrument ever played on, cause well strung,
Who's that come into the chamber there? O, Mr. Cargo.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.p: My lord hath sent you a jewel, locked up in this paper, and the moisture of a goose quill, that's to say, words in that —

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: O sir, I thank your lord, and this your pains; have him into the buttery — let me see, lady, that I love you, I dare swear like a lord (I shall have oaths enough then) I send you all that is mine, in hope all shall be mine that is yours, for it stands to reason, that mine being yours, yours should be mine, and yours being mine, mine should be yours. Love me, or I die, if I die, you kill me, if you kill me, I will say nothing, but take the blow patiently. I hold my life this lord has been bastinadoed, out upon him rammish fox, he stinks hither; prithee good brother read.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Is't gander month with him? How the devil is my maidenhead blasted? that among such shoals of gallants, that swim up and down the court, no fish bites at the bait of my poor beauty, but this tough codshead?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: O sister, peace for heaven's sake; here lies health
Even in this bitter pill (For me) so you
Would play but my physician, and say, take it;
You are offered here, to sojourn at his house:
Companion with his lady.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Sir, I have you. And I going upon so weighty a business, as getting of children, you would ha' me pin you to my sleeve.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: You care not so I turn whore to pleasure you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: O sister, your high worth is known full well
'Gainst base assault, a fort impregnable;
And therefore, as you love my life, ith' springe,
Catch this old woodcock.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: In the flame I'll sing
My wings, unless I put the candle out,
That you i'th' darke may bring your hopes about.
You have won me.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You revive me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Have a care you cast not yourself down too soon now.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: As for my old huckster's artillery, I have walls of
Chastity strong enough shoot he never so hard, to keep him
From making any breach.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: 'Twill be a noble-battle on each side;
Yet now my spirits are roused, a stratagem
Lies hatching here, pray help me noble sister,
To give it form and life.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: My best.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What think you?
(The mark of man not yet set in my face)
If as your sister, or your kinswoman,
I go in woman's habit, for thereby,
Speech, free access, fair opportunity;
Are had without suspicion.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Mine be your will;
O me! what pains we take to bring forth ill!
Such a disguise is safe too, since you never but once
Were seen there.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: My wise sister ever.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Send in the fellow there that brought the letter;
Why how now? do his legs fail him already?
A staff for his declining age.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: I have a pikestaff of mine own already, but I could not
Keep our your scurvy desperate hogshead from coming
In upon me, I'm cut i'th' coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Nothing I see is so like an old-man, as a young man drunk.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: Or when he comes from a wench.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Before he bear your answer let him sleep.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Whilst you laugh at what I could almost weep.
sp.stage: Enter Angelo, like a doctor, Baptista, his man.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Dear friend, I should both wrong my faith and fortunes,
sp.p: To make 'em thus dance antics; I shall never play the dissembler.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Then never play the lover;
Death! for a woman, I'd be flayed alive,
Could I but find one constant: is't such a matter
For you then to put on a doctors-gown,
And his flat velvet-cap, and speak the gibbering
Of an apothecary.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: If thus disguised
I'm taken all the physic in the world
Cannot prolong my life.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: And dying for her,
You venture bravely, all women o'er you grave
Will pray that they so kind a man may have,
As to die for 'em; say your banishment
Had born you hence, what hells of discontent,
Had racked your soul for her as hers for you?
Should you but faint, well might you seem untrue,
Where this attempt your loyalty shall approve,
Who ventures farthest wins a ladies-love.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How are my beard and hair?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Friend I protest,
So rarely counterfeit, as if a painter
Should draw a doctor: were I sick myself,
And met you with an urinal in my hand,
I'd cast it at your head, unless you cast
The water for me, come, all's passing well;
Love which makes pale the cheeks, gives you complexion,
Fit for a sallow Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will on then,
In France I long have lived, and know the garb
Of the french-mounte-bankes, whose apish gesture,
Although in them I hold ridiculous,
Myself shall practise.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: For a doctors-man,
You see I'm fitted, foot by foot I'll walk,
And meet all dangers sent against your breast.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I thank thee noble friend; let's then to court.
The pangs a lover suffers are but short.
sp.stage: Enter Florence, Pisa, Nicolletto, Philippo, tonell, Piero, met by an old nurse.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How now nurse, how does my Fiametta?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: O my sweet lord, she's at it again, at it again!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Who are with her? call for more help.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: More help! alas there's my lady Vanni with her, and ladies upon ladies, and doctors upon doctors, but all cannot do.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: How does it take her nurse?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: O sweet Princess, it takes her all over with a pricking; first about her stomach, and then she heaves and heaves, that no one man with all his weight, can keep her down.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: At this I wonder, that her sickness makes her doctors fools.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: He that she finds most ease in, is dr. Jordan.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will give half my dukedom for her health.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Well, well, if death do take her, he shall have the sweetest bedfellow that ever lay by lean mans-side.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I entreat thee nurse be tender over her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Tender quoth 'a? I'm sure my heels are grown as hard as hooves, with trotting for her, I'll put you in one comfort.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What's that nurse?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: In her greatest conflict sh'as had a worthy feeling of herself.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So, so, I'm glad of it my lord of Pisa.
Under this common blow, which might have struck the
Strongest heart, here pray do not you shrink.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Sickness is life's retainer, sir, and I
(What is not to be shunned) bear patiently;
But had she health as sound as hath the spring,
She would to me prove sickly autumn still.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O say not so,

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I find it, for being loyal,
As the touch-needle to one star still turning,
I lose that star, my faith is paid with scorning.
Who then with eagle's wings of faith and truth,
Would in her sunbeams play away his youth,
And kiss those flames, which burn but out mine eyes,
with scalding rivers of her cruelties?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Tis but her wayward sickness casts this eye of slightness on you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: 'Tis my lord her hate;
For when death sits even almost on her brows,
She spreads her arms abroad, to welcome him,
When in my bridal-bed I find a grave.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now Mutio?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: There's a Frenchman come to court,
A professed doctor, that has seen the Princess,
And will on her recovery pawn his life.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Comfort from heaven, I hope, let's see this doctor.
sp.stage: Enter Angelo like a doctor, Baptista his man.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Welcome good doctor: have you seen my daughter?
Restore her health, and nothing in my dukedom,
Shall be too dear for thee, how do you judge her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Be me trat me lord, I find her a very bad lady, and no well.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Piero take the Duke of Pisa pray and be your sister's visi.

sp.speaker: Piero.
sp.l: Sir we shall, if the Duke please — (Tants.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: The poisoned may drink gall.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Attend the Duke.

sp.speaker: Caego.
sp.l: The party sir.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Thou shalt have Caesar's pay — my coach,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Old January goes to lie with may.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Doctor I thus have singled you, to sound
The depth of my girl's sickness, that if no skill
Of man can save her, I against heavens will,
May arm my breast with patience, therefore be free.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: By my tra' and fa'my lor ', me no point can play
The hound, and fawn upon de most puissant roy in de world;
A Frenchman bear the brave mind for dat.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So, so, I like him better.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Me gra tank you, now for de malady of de Princess,
Me one two, tre time, feel her pulse, and ron up and down all
De oder parts of her body, and find noting but dat
She be trobla with le gran desire of de man.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A great desire of a man?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A my trat 'tis verament, she longa to do some ting in love uponle gentle home.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Doctor thou hittest her heart, 'tis there she's wounded,
By a poisoned arrow, shot from a villain's hand;
One Angelo of the Lotti family,
And till that head be plucked out, she will pine,
Unless controlled by some deep art of thine.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: All tings possibela me fall undergo, me ha' read Galen,
sp.p: Hippocratus, Avicen, but no point can peek out le remedy for de madam in de briars of love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No medicine you say in any of them for love.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Aim, trat not worth a louse, only in my peregrination about le grand globe of de world, me find out a fine trick for make a de man, and woman do, dat is tickla in love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: The man and the woman do? how do, how do?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: To be cura, and all whole, admirable vell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As how prey?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Me have had under my fingera, many brave vench, and most noble gentle dames, dat have be much troubla, upon de wild vorme in de tail for de man.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And be my troth my lord, by experiment me find dat de heart of de man; you understanda me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, yes, the heart of the man.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We we, de heart of de man being all dry as peppera.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So so.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And rub upon de ting (Vat you call it) fall make it moulder all to crumble and dust.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O, o, a grater.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ee by my troth you say vell, rub a de man's dry art upon de grater, and drink de powder in de pot le vine, by de gentlewoman, and by gars-blor, she presentamently kick up de heel at de man she lova.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No point more remembra, but cry out le French po upon le varlet.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: So she will hate her lover.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Begar, as myself hate le puz-cat, cry mew at my shin; and vill have de rambling a de gut, for de other gentle home.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thou comest up close to me now, my brave doctor.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Begar me hope so, and derfore my lord apply le desperate
medicine, to le perilous malady, and have dis Angelo be cut in de troate, and be manslaughtered.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You then advise me to have Angelo slain.

sp.speaker: Ang,
sp.l: We.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And then to have my daughter drink his heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We, we.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Grated and dried, and so —

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We, we, we.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I would I gripped it fast now in this hand,
And eat it panting hot, to teach a peasant
To climb above his being, doctor, he dies.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Knocka de pate down begar.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But stay, stay, he's fled Florence; it will be
A work to find him first out, and being found,
A task to kill him; for our gallants speak
Much of his worth; the varlet is valiant.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No matera for dat; for-two tree four crown, dar be
Rascals fall run him in on de backside.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: He shall be sought for, and being found, he dies.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray my lord suffera le Princess and me for be in private,
Le doctor uses for toucha do ooman —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do, so, whilst I for Angelo's death use speed,
For till I have his heart, mine own must bleed.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O my Baptista.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: I have heard the thunder aimed at your life.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And it will strike me dead,
With a most sudden and invisible blow.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Now that you see his vengeance apt to fall,
Fly from it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: By fair, and free access,
Open your dangers to your mistress eyes,
Where she stark mad, so she be mad for love,
You'll bring her to her wits, if wisely now
You put her into th'way; gold barred with locks,
Is best being stolen; steal her then.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis but a wrack at most,
O on what boisterous seas is true love tossed!

div.head: Actus tertius. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Trumpets sounding. Enter an usher bare, perfuming a room, signior Torrenti gorgeously attired, a company of gallants.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: This room smells.

sp.speaker: 1. Gal.
sp.l: It has been new perfumed.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Then 'tis your breeches; stand off — and shines there (Say you) a sun in our horizon full as glorious, as we ourself?

sp.speaker: 2. Gal.
sp.l: So cry the common people.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: The common people are rascals, lying devils,
Dunghills, whose savour poisons brave men's fames,
That ape of greatness (Imitating me)
I mean that slavish lord Jacomo
Shall die a beggar, if at the year's end,
His total of expense dares equal mine;
How is his house built?

sp.speaker: 1. Gal.
sp.l: Admirable fair.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Fair? I'll guild mine (Like Pompey's theater)
All o'er to outshine his; the richest hangings
Persian, or Turk, or Indian slaves can weave,
Shall from my purse be bought at any rates;
I'll pave my great hall with a floor of clouds,
Wherein shall move an artificial sun,
Reflecting round about me, golden beams,
Whose flames shall make the room seem all on fire,
And when 'tis night, just as that sun goes down,
A silver moon shall rise, drawn up by stars,
And as that moves, I standing in her orb,
Will move with her, and be that man ith' moon,
So mocked in old wives tales; then over head,
A roof of woods, and forests full of deer,
Trees growing downwards, full of singing quires.
And this I'll do that men with praise, may crown
My fame, for turning the world upside down:
And what brave gallants are Gentili's guests?

sp.speaker: 1. Gal.
sp.l: The lord Jacomo Gentili feeds
all beggars at his table.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Hang Jacome,
My board shall be no manger for poor jades
To lick up provender in.

sp.speaker: 2. Gal.
sp.l: He welcomes soldiers.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Let soldiers beg and starve, or steal and hang.
Would I had here ten-thousand soldiers heads,
Their skulls set all in silver, to drink healths
To his confusion, first invented war,
And the health drunk to drown the bowls i'th sea,
That very name of soldier, makes me shrug,
And think I crawl with vermin; give me lutes,
Mischief on drums, for soldiers; fetch me whores,
These are men's bliss; those every kingdoms soars,
We gave in charge to search through all the world
For the best cooks, rarest musicians,
And fairest girls, that will sell sin for gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Gal.
sp.l: Some of all sorts you have

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Let me have more
Than the grand signior, and my change as rare,
Tall, low, and middle size, the brown, and fair;
I'd give a prince's ransom now to kiss
Black Cleopatra's cheek; only to drink
A richer pearl, than that of Anthony's,
That fame (Where his name stands) might put down mine.
O that my mother had been Paris whore,
And I had lived to see a Troy on fire,
So that by that brave light, I might have danced
But one lavalto with my courtesan.

sp.speaker: 4. Gal.
sp.l: Pattern of all perfection breathed in man,
There's one without, before your excellence
Desires access.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: What creature?

sp.speaker: 4. Gal.
sp.l: Your own brother,
At least he terms himself so.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Is he brave?

sp.speaker: 4. Gal.
sp.l: He's new come from sea.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: 'Tis true, that Jason
Rigged out a fleet to fetch the golden-fleece;
'Tis a brave boy, all elemental fire,
His ships are great with child of Turkish treasure,
And here shall be delivered; marshal him in
like the seas proud commander give our charge —

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Sound drums, and trumpets, for my lord away.
sp.stage: Usher him in Pare and ragged. At which Torrenti starts, his hat falls off, offer it him.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Thou whoreson peasant, know me, burn that windfall,
It comes not to my head that drops so low, — another

sp.speaker: 1. gall
sp.l: Hats for my lord, — hats brought in 3. or 4.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: It smells of earth, stood it again so high,
My head would on a dunghill seem to lie.
How now? what scarecrow's this?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Scarecrow? thy brother,
His blood clear as thine own, but that it smokes not,
With perfumed fires as thine doth.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Has the poor snake, a sting; can he hiss?
What begs the rogue for?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Vengeance
From the just thunderer to throw Lucifer down;
How high soever thou rearest thy babell-browes,
To thy confusion I this language speak:
I am thy father's son.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, the skipper raves.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: The awed Venetian on st. marks proud-day,
Never went forth to marry the rich-sea,
With casting in her lap a ring of gold;
In greater bravery than myself did fraught,
A fleet of gallant youthful Florentines,
All vowed to rescue Rhodes, from turkish-slavery:
We went and waded up in our own bloods,
Till most of us were drowned.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Fair riddance on you.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Where such a peacock durst not spread his plumes;
We fought and those that fell left monuments
Of unmatched valour to the whole race of man,
They that were taken, (Amongst whom myself was chief)
Were three years chained up to the tugging o'er,
See here the relics of that misery, chains,
If thou wouldst know more, read it on my back,
Printed with the bulls-pizzle.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Hang the dog.
What tellest thou me of peezeles?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: 'Tis thy brother tells thee so, note me.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: I know thee not;
Set mastiffs on him, worry him from my gates.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: The first unhappy breath I drew, moved here,
And here I'll spend my last, ere braved from hence,
Here I'll have meat and clothes.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Kick the cur out.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: Who dares?
Take from that sumpter-horses back of thine,
Some of those gaudy trappings to clothe mine,
And keep it from the keen air, fetch me food,
You fawning spaniels

sp.speaker: 1. gall
sp.l: Some spirit of the buttery.

sp.speaker: 2. gall
sp.l: It should be by his hunger.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: I am starved,
Thirsty, and pined to th'bare bones, here; I'll eat at thine
Own scornful board, on thine own meat, or tear it from
Thy throat as 'tis chewing down.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: I'll try that; if my dinner be prepared,
Serve me in my great state alongst this way,
And as you pass two there with pistols stand.
To kill that ravenous vulture; if he dare thrust his talents
Forth to make one dish his prey.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Now view my face, and though perhaps you shamed
To own so poor a brother, let not my heartstrings,
In sunder crack, if we now being lone,
You still disdain me.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Wretch I know thee not,
And loathe thy sight.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Slave, thou shalt know me then;
I'll beat thy brains out with my galley-chain.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Wilt murder thine own brother?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Pride doth itself confound,
What with both hands the devil strove to have bound,
Heaven with one little finger hath untied,
This proves that thou mayest fall, because one blast
Shakes thee already, fear not, I'll not take
The whip out of your hand and though thou breakest
Laws of humanity, and brotherhood;
I'll not do so, but as a beggar should
(Not as a brother) knock I at the gate
Of thy hard heart for pity to come forth,
And look upon my wretchedness, a shot
Tore to the keel that galley where I rowed;
Sunk her, the men slain, I by diving scaped,
And sat three leagues upon a broken-mast,
Washed with the salt tears of the sea, which wept,
In pity, to behold my misery.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Pox on your, tarry misery.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: And when heavens blest-hand hauled me to ashore
To dry my wet-limbs, was I forced to fire,
A deadman's straw-bed thrown into the street.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Foh, thou'rt infectious.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: O remember this!
He that does good deeds, here waits at a table,
Where angels are his fellow servitors.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: I am no robin-redbreast to bring straws
To cover such a corse.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Thou art turned devil,
sp.stage: Trumpets sound. Enter an armed sewer, after him a company with covered dishes: coronets on their heads. Two with pistols to guard it.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Where's thy great stomach, eat, stand, let him choose
What dish he likes. — snatches a pistol: ill fly off.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: This then which I'll carve up
On thy base bosom, see thou trivial fool,
Thou art a tyrant (O'er me) of short reign,
This cock out crows thee, and thy petty Kings,
Thou'rt a proud-bird, but fliest with rotten wings;
To show how little for thy scorn I care,
See my revenge turns all to idle-air,
It upward flies and will from thence I fear
Shoot darts of lightning to confound thee here.
Farewell thou huge Leviathan, when thou'st drunk dry,
That sea thou rowlest in, on some base shore die.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Where is the traitor?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Now the house is fired,

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: You come to cast on waters; bar up my doors,
But one such tattered ensign here being spread,
Draws numbers hither, here must no rogues be fed;
Command my carpenters invent odd engines.
To manacle base beggars, hands and feet,
And by my name call 'em my whipping posts;
If you spy any man that has a look,
Stigmatically drawn, like to a fury's,
(Able to fright) to such I'll give large pay,
To watch and ward for poor snakes night and day,
And whip 'em soundly if they approach my gates;
The poor are but the earths-dung fit to lie
Covered on much-heaps not to offend the eye.

sp.speaker: 1. gall
sp.l: Two gentlemen sent from the Florence Duke,
Require speech with your lordship —

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Give 'em entrance
What re you? and whence come you?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: From the Duke.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Your business?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: This, fame sounding forth your worth
For hospitable princely housekeeping;
Our Duke drawn by the wonder of report,
Invites himself (By us) to be your guest.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: The honour of ambassadors be yours;
Say to the Duke that Caesar never came;
More welcome to the Capitol of Rome,
Than he to us — healths to him — fill rich wines.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: You have this wonder wrought, now rare to men;
By you they have found the golden age again.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Which I'll uphold, so long as there's a sun,
To play the alchemist.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This proud fellow talks
As if he grasped the Indies in each hand.

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: Health to your Duke.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: We pledge it on our knees.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: I'll stand to what I do, but kneel to none.
sp.stage: Music, drink, break the glass, they pledge it in plate, which offering, both servitors refuse to take.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Break not our custom (Pray ye) with one beam;
The god of metals makes both gold and wine
to imitate whose greatness; if on you
I can bestow wine, I can give gold too,
Take them as free as Bacohus spends his blood;
And in them drink our health.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Your bounty far
Exceeds that of our Caesars.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Caesar ero, vel nihil ero:
What are gold heaps? but a rich dust for Kings
To scatter with their breath, as chaff by wind?
Let him then that hath gold, bear a King's mind,
And give till his arm aches, who bravely powers
But into a wench's lap his golden showers,
May be Jove's equal, o but he that spends
A world of wealth, makes a whole world his debtor,
And such a noble spender is Jove's better;
That man I'll be, I'm Alexander's heir
To one part of his mind, I wish there were
Ten worlds, yet not to conquer, but to sell.
For Alpine hills of silver, and that I.
Might at one feast, spend all that treasure dry;
Who hoards up wealth, is base; who spends it, brave,
Earth breeds gold, so I tread but on my slave;
Bear back our gratulations to your Duke.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: We shall great sir.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Torrenti call you him; 'tis a proud rough stream.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He's of the Roman family indeed.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Lord Vanni? rather my lord Vanity.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And heaps of money sure have struck him mad.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: He'll soon pick up his wits, let him but bleed
Thus many ounces at one time; all day
Could I drink these dear healths, yet ne'er be drunk.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And carry it away most cleanly.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Not a pin the worse;
What might his father leave him?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A great estate,
Of some 300000 crowns a year.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Strange he's not begged, for fools are now grown
An admirable coxcomb! (Dear;

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Let wonder pass,
He's both a brave-lord, and a golden ass.
sp.stage: A bed discovered, Eyametta upon it. Enter two Dukes, Piero, gallants, nurse, ladies, Angelo, Baptista, ut antea Fyametta.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I pray you hush all, a little hush, le fair lady by he own vo unter disposition, has take a ting dat is of such a grand operation, it shall make a de stone for sleep.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What, noble doctor, is the name of it?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Tis not your scurvy English poppy, nor mandragon, nor a ting so danger as oppium, but 'tis de brave ting a de vorld, for knock a de brain asleep.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am glad she takes this rest.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Peace, be gour it is snore and snore, two mile long; now if your grace vill please for procure music, be restore as brave as de fish.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Call for the music.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Makea no noise, but bring in de fiddlers, and play sweet --

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.p: O out upon this doctor; hang him, does he think to cure dejected ladies with fiddlers —

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: De grand French poo stopa de troat, pray void le shambera.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: All, all part softly; peace nurse, let her sleep.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Ay, ay, go out of her prospect, for she's not to be cured with a song.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Baptista, see the door fast, watch that narrowly.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.p: For one friend to keep door for another, is the office now amongst gallants, common as the law; I'll be your porter sir.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: She does but slumber, Fiametta, love.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: The Pisan prince comes: daggers at my heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Look up, I am not he, but Angelo?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Ha! who names Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Angelo himself,
Who with one soot treads on the throat of death,
Whilst tother steps to embrace thee, thus ith' shape
Of a French doctor.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: O my life, my soul.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: I me now not sick, I'll have no physic,
But what thyself shall give me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let not joy confound our happiness, I am but dead,
If it be known I am here.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Thou shalt not hence.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Be wise dear heart; see here the best of men,
Faithful Baptista — — —

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: O, I love Baptista,
'Cause he loves thee; but my Angelo I love 'bove Kings.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Madam you'll spoil,
Unless you join with us in the safe plot
Of our escape.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sweet Fiametta hear me.
For you shall hence with us.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Over ten worlds,
But I'll not hence; my Angelo shall not hence,
True love, like gold, is best being tried in fire;
I'll defy father, and a thousand deaths — for thee — —

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: At the court gate,
I see a jebbit already, to hang's both;
Death! the Duke beats at the door.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: He shall come in;
One frown at thee, my tragedy shall begin;
See father —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I told you that I heard — her tongue —

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: See father. Flo what sweet girl?

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: That's Angelo, and you shall pardon him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: He says he pardons thee with all his heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Me lor, be all mad, le brain crow, and run whereabout like de windmill sail, pardon a moy, por quoy my sweet madam, pardon your povera doctor.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Because thou art my banish't Angelo.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Starke mad.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: This her recovery?

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: He is no doctor,
Nor that his man, but his dear friend Baptista;
Has blacked this beard like a comedian
To play the mountebank; away, I'll marry
None but that doctor, and leave Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I do pray artely, madam.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Leave off thy gibberish, and I prithee speak
thy native language.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Par-ma-soy all French be-gor she be mad as the moon.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sweet girl, with gentle hands sir, take her hence.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Stand from me, I must follow Angelo.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Thine eyes drink sleep from the sweet god of rest.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: O, you shoot poisoned arrows thorough my breast.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What strange new fury now possesseth her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Begar her imaginashon be out a de vitts, and so dazzle de two nyes, and come down so into de belly, and possibla for make her tinke me or you to be le gentleman she lovea, and so she takea my man for a jackanapes, me know not who.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: For one Baptista.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Povera garshon a my trat.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I do believe you both, but honest doctor,
Strain all thy art, and so thou leave her well,
I care not if you call up fiends from hell.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Dar be too much devil in de body all ready be my trat my lord, me no stay here for ten hundred hundred coronas, she cry upon me 'tis master Angelo, you tink so not one and two time, but a tired time, you smell a me out; and so cutta my troate; adieu my lord.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Still your opinion holds to kill that villain,
And give her his heart dried.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: In de pot a vine, we, very fine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This gold take for thy pains to make her sound,
There needs a desperate cure to a desperate wound.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How blows it now?

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Fair, with a prosperous gale.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Poor love, thou still art struck with thine own fate;
My life hangs at a thread, friend I must fly.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: How, to be safe?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will take sanctuary,
I know a reverend friar, in whose cell
I'll lurk till storms blow o'er; if women knew
What men feel for them, none their scorns should rue.
sp.stage: Enter Tibaldo in woman's attire, Alphonsina.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p:
Is't come to this, have the walls of the castle been besieged
thus long, lain open for a breach; and dare you not
sp.l: Give fire to once piece? o you're a proper soldier, good
Sister, brother follow your game more close, or I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Why I would ha'you (Tho' you be in woman's apparel) to be yourself a man, and do what you come for.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I have been giving her a thousand on sets,
And still a blushing cheek makes me retire;
I speak not three words, but my tongue is ready
To ask forgiveness of her.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Must thou needs at thy first encounter tell her thou art a man, why when you walk together, cannot you begin a tale to her, with once upon a time there was a loving couple that having tired themselves with walking, sat down upon a bank, and kissed, and embraced, and played, and so by degrees bring the tale about to your own purpose. Can you not? fie, you are the worst at these things sir.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am sister indeed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: And the more fool you indeed: you see how the old stinking fox her husband is still rubbing me as if I had the palsy, I'll not have his withered hands (Which are as moist as the side of stockfish) lie piddling in my bosom, therefore determine some thing, or farewell.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I have dear sister, if you will but hear me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Come on, out with't then.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Give you the old man promise of your love,
And the next night appoint him for your bed;
Raped with joy, he'll feign business of state,
To leave his lady, and to lie alone,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Then my request shall be, that for that night
She would accept me for her bedfellow,
And there's no question sister of the grant,
Which being enjoyed I doubt not but to manage
And carry all so even on levill ground,
That my offence shall in my love seem drowned.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: The clock for your business thus far goes true, but now for me, what shall I do with the old cock in my roost?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Sister, you have some trick (No doubt) to keep
Him within compass.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p:
No not I believe me, I know not what to do with him,
unless I should give him a little nux vomica, to make him sleep away the night, but brother, to pleasure you, I'll venture a joint, and yet it troubles me too, that I should prove a traitor to my sex, I do betray an innocent lady, to what ill I know not.
sp.l: But love the author of it will I hope
Turn it quite otherwise, and perhaps it may be
So welcome to her as a courtesy.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I doubt not but it shall.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: We nothing can,
Unless man woman help, and woman man.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Trumpets sounding. Enter Torrenti very brave, between the two Dukes, attended by all the courtiers, wondering at his costly habit. Enter a mask, woman in strange habits, Danee. Exit. He gives jewels, and ropes of pearl to the Duke; and a chain of gold to every courtier. Exit. Nicholetto and he stay.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Thou art my noble kinsman, and but thy mother
(Upon my soul) was chaste I should believe
Some emperor begotten thee,

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Why pray uncle?

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Suppose all kingdoms on the earth were balls,
And that thou held'st a racket in thy hand,
To toss 'em as thou wouldst, how wouldst thou play?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Why? as with balls, bandy 'em quite away.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: A tennis-court of Kings could do no more;
But faith what dost thou think, that I now think,
Of thy this days expense?

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: That it was brave.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I think thee a proud vainglorious bragging knave,
That golden womb thy father left so full, thou
Vulturelike eatest through: o here's trimstuff;
A goodman's state, in garters, strings and ruff;
Hast not a saffron shirt on too? I fear thou'rt
Troubled with the green-sickness, thou lookest wan.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: With anger at thy snarling must my hose
Match your old greasy codpiece?

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: No, but I'd have thee live in compass.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Fool, I'll be
As the sun in the zodiac; I am he
that wood take Phaeton's fall, though I set fire
On the whole world to be heaven's charioteer,
(As he was) but one day.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Vain riotous coxcomb,
Thou'st fired to much already, parks, forests, chases,
Have no part left of them, but names and places;
'Tis voiced abroad thy lands are all at pawn.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: They are, what then?

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: And that the money went to
Entertain the Pope's great nuntio,
On whom you spent the ransom of a King.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I thank you sir,

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Say all this true
That I spent millions, what's that to you.
Were there for every day i'th' year a Pope,
For every hour i'th' year a Cardinal;
I'd melt both Indies, but I'd feast 'em all.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: And leave your courtesans bare, that leaving bare,
Will one day leave thee naked, one nights waking,
With a fresh-whore, cost thee 4000. ducats,
Else the bawd lies.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Wert thou not mine uncle
I'd send thee with thy frozen-beard where furies
Should sing it off with firebrands, touching
Wenching, that art thyself an old rotten whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I a whoremaster?
To show how much I hate it, hark, when next thy tumblers
Come to dance upon the ropes,
Play this jig to 'em.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: Go, go, idle drone,
Thou enviest bees with stings, because thine is gone,
Plate, jewels, revenues all shall fly.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: They shall.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.l: And then sir I'll turn pickled thief, a pirate,
For as I to feed rayot, a world did crave,
So nothing but the sea shall be my grave,
Mean time that circle few began L've run, though the
Devil stand i'th' centre.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: What's that circle?

sp.speaker: Torr.
sp.l: The vanity of all mankind be mine,
in me all prodigals looseness fresh shall flow,
Wine, harlots, surfeits, rich embroidered clothes,
Fashions, all sensual sins, all new coined oaths,
Shall feed me, fill me; I'll feast every sense,
Naught shall become me ill, but innocence.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I hope a wallet hanging at thy back,
Who spends all young, ere age comes, all will lack.
sp.stage: Enter an apothecary give a servingman gold, Jacomo, servants in blue-coats: Stew. broker, goldsmith, Torrenti's brother, a trumpet.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What sounds this trumpet for?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Dinner my lord,

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: To feast whom this day are my tables spread?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: For seamen, wracked, aged, or sick, or lame,
And the late ransomed captives from the Turk.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Cheer them with hearty welcomes in my name,
Attend them as great lords, let no man dare,
To send 'em sad hence, bounty shall be placed
At the boards upper end; for mariners
Are clocks of danger that do never stand still,
Their dials-hand ere points to'th stroke of death,
And (Albeit seldom windless) lose their breath;
I love 'em, for they eat the dearest bread,
That life can buy, when the elements make wars;
Water and air, they are said by their good stars.
And for the galley-slaves, make much of those, love that man
Who suffers only for being christian; what suitors wait?

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Come near, one at once, keep back pray.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: A sorry man, a very sorry man.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: What makes thee sorry?

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.p: All I had is burned, and that which touches me to the quick, a box of my sweet evidence my lord.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Show me some proof of this.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: Alas too good proof, all burned, nor stick, nor stone, left.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What wouldst have me do?

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: Bestow but a bare 100. l. on me, to set me up.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Steward deliver him a 100. l.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: Now all the —

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nay kneel not sir, but hear me.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: O my honey lord!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Faces are speaking pictures, thine's a book,
Which if the leaf be truly printed shows
A page of close dissembling.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: O my lord!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But say thou art such, yet the money's thine,
Which I to charity give, not to her shrine;
If thou cheatest me, thou art cheated? how? thou'st got
(Being liquorish) ratsbane from a galley-pot,
Taking it for sugar; thou art now my debtor,
I am not hurt, nor thou I fear, much better; farewell.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Cannons defend me, gunpowder of hell,
Whom dost thou blow up here?

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: Some honest scullar, row this lame dog to hanging.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: My lord calls to you.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Was there ever called
A devil by name from hell? than this is one.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My friend, what is he?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: A city pestilence,
A moth that eats up gowns, doublets and hose,
One that with bills, leads smocks and shirts together
To linen close adultery, and upon them
Strews lavender, so strongly, that the owners
Dare never smell them after; he's a broker.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Suppose all this, what hurt hath he done thee?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: More than my limbs loss; in one week he eat
My wife up, and three children, this christian Jew did;
Has a long lane of hellish tenements,
Built all with pawns.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: All that he had is burned.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: He keeps a whore indeed, this is the raven,
Cried knock before you call, he may be fired,
His lousy wardrobes are not; to this hellhound
I pawned my weapons to buy brown bread
To seed my brats and me; (They forfeited)
Twice so much as his money him I gave,
To have my arms redeemed, the griping slave
Swore (Not to save my soul) unless that I
Laid down my stump here, for the interest,
And so hop home.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Unheard of villain!
Broker, is this true?

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: 'Twere sin my lord, to lie.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Soldier, what is't thou now cravest at my hands?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: This my petition was, which now I tear,
My suit here was, when the next place did fall,
to be a beadsman in your hospital:
But now I come most piteous complaining
Against this three-pile rascal, widow's decayer,
The orphan's beggerer, and the poors betrayer;
Give him the Russian law for all these sins.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: But one hundred blows on his bare shins

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: Come home and take thine arms.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I'll have those legs

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Broker, my soul foresaw goods thus ill got,
Would as ill thrive, you asked a hundred pound,
'Tis yours; but crafty broker, you played the knave
To beg, not needing. This man now must have
His request too, 'tis honest, fair, and just,
Take hence that varlet therefore, and on his shins,
In ready payment, give him an hundred blows.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: My lord, my pitiful lord.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I must bestir my stumps too. Justice; my lord.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will not ravel out time; broker, I offer you
A hundred for a hundred.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: That's his own usury.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A hundred pound, or else a hundred blows,
Give him that money, he shall release you those.

sp.speaker: Broker
sp.l: Take it, and mayest thou rot with't.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Follow thee thy curse,
Would blows might make all brokers still disburse.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What next?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: The party sir:

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What party sir?
If honest, speak, I love no whisperer.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: This gentleman is a great shuter.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: In a longbow? how far shoots he?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: To your lordship, to be your apothecary.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Umph; what spy you in my face, that I should buy
Your drugs and drenches? bears not my cheek a colour
As fresh as any old man's? do my bones
Ache with youth's riots? or my blood boil hot
With fevers? or is't numbed with dropsies, cold
Coughs, rheums, catarrhs, gouts, apoplexy fits?
The common sores of age, on me never ran,
Nor Galenist, nor Paracelsian,
Shall ere read physical lecture upon me.

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.l: Two excellent fellows my lord.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I honour their profession,
What the creator does, they in part do,
For a physician's a man-maker too, — but honest friend,
My kitchen is my doctor, and my garden,
Trusty apothecary; when they give me pills,
So gently work they, I'm not choked with bills,
Which be a stronger purge than the disease.

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.l: Alas my lord, and 'twere not for bills, our shops would

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir, I believe you, bills nor pills I'll take; (Down.
I stand on sickness shore, and see men tossed
From one disease to another, at last lost;
But to such seas of surfeits, where they're drowned,
I never venturing, am ever sound.

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.p: Ever sound my lord? if all our gallants should be so, doctors, pothecaries, and barber-surgeons, might feed upon onions and buttermilk; ever sound! A brave world then.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis their own fault, if they fear springs or falls,
Wineglasses filled too fast, make urinals;
Man was at first born sound, and he grows ill
Seldom by course of nature, but by will —
Distempers are not ours, there should be then
(Were we ourselves) no physic, men to men
Are both diseases cause, and the disease,
I'm free from (Thanks good fate) either of these.

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.l: My 50. Crowns.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.l: No, must I give you a glister?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Hist, hist.

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.p: If your lordship will not allow me minister to yourself, pray let me give your man a purgation.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Me a purgation? my lord, I'm passing well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Him a purge, why?

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.l: Or rather a vomit, that he may cast up 50 crowns —
Which he swallowed as a bribe to prefer me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My health is bought and sold sir then by you,
A doctor baits you next, whose mesh of potions
Striking me full of ulcers, a gibberish surgeon,
For 50. Crown's more, comes to draw my will,
For money, slaves their sovereigns thus kill;
Nay, nay, so got, so keep it; for his fifty,
give him a 100. Crowns, because his will
Aimed at my health I know, and not at ill:
Fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Apothecary
sp.l: Who pays me sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Follow me, I sir.
sp.stage: Exit Sar. and apothe. Enter goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Gold.
