sp.l: The fellow, my lord, is fast.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What fellow sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.l: The thief that stole this jewel from your honour,
He came unto my stall my lord.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.l: And asked me
Not the fourth part in money it was worth,
And so smelling him out.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You did.

sp.speaker: Golds.
sp.l: I did sir,
Smell him out presently, and under hand
Sent for a constable, examined him,
And finding that he is your steward's man,
Committed him toth' jail.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: What money had he upon this jewel of you?

sp.speaker: Golds.
sp.l: None my good lord, after I heard it yours.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Else you had bought it,
And been the thief's receiver, you're a varlet,
Go to, a saucy knave; if I want money;
And send my servant's servant (Cause the world
Shall not take notice of it) to pawn, or sell
Jewels, or plate, though I lose half in half,
Must you sir, play the marshal, and commit him,
As if he were a rogue; go and release him,
Send him home presently, and pay his fees, do you see sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.l: My lord, I do see.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Lest by the innocent fellow,
I lay you fast byth' heels, do this you're best;
You may be gone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.l: Here's a most excellent jest.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Hark you, the Duke of Florence sent me once
A jewel, have ye'it? For you laid it up.

sp.speaker: Steward
sp.l: My lord, I have it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Are you sure you have it?
Why change you colour? Know you this? do you know
Your man, you sent to sell it? You belike
Thought in my memory it had been dead,
And so your honesty too came buried,
'Tis well, out of mine eye; what would you with me?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Your pity on a wretch late wracked at sea,
Beaten ashore by penury, 3 . years a Turkish
Galleyslave.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your birth?

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Such sir,
As I dare write myself a gentleman,
In Florence stood my cradle, my house great,
In money, not in mercy; I am poor,
And dare not with the beggar pass their door.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Name them, they shall be forced to thy relief.
To steal compassion from them like a thief,
Good my lord pardon me, under your noble wing,
I had rather sit, then on the highest tree sing,
That shadows their gay buildings.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Young man I do commend thee, where's my steward?
Give me thy hand, I entertain thee mine,
Make perfect your accounts, and see the books delivered
To this gentleman.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: This poor rogue sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Thou art a villain, so to term the man,
Whom I to liking take; sir I discharge you;
I regard no man's outside, 'tis the linings
Which I take care for,

sp.speaker: St.
sp.l: Not if you knew how lousy they were.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Cast not thy scorn upon him, prove thou but just,
I'll raise the cedars spring out first from dust.
sp.stage: Enter Nicolletto, Dariene, Alphons, Alisandra, Tibaldo, Cargo.

sp.speaker: Nie.
sp.l: Madam this night I have received from court,
A book of deep import, which I must read,
And for that purpose will I he alone.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Be Mr. of your own content my lord.
I'll change you for some female bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Pray madam then take me.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Do prithee wife.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: And sr. she is most welcome.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Would I were at it, for it is a book,
My fingers itch till I be turning o'er;
Good rest fair Alphonsina you'll not fail.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: No, fear me not.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: All all to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Mine eyes are full of sleep; I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: I to my closet, and then bedfellow
Expect your company

sp.speaker: Tibal.
sp.l: I will be for your lady.

sp.speaker: Aless.
sp.l: Madam so please you forfeit to my mother,
And let yourself and I be bedfellows.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Dear heart I humbly thank you, but I must not.

sp.speaker: Aless.
sp.l: Lady I rather wish your company,
Because I know one maiden best conceals,
What's bosomed in another: but I'll wait
With patience a time fitting.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Worthy lady,
This time is yours and mine.

sp.speaker: Aless.
sp.l: Thus I begin then,
And if I cannot woe relief from you,
Let me at least win pity, I have fixed
Mine eye upon your brother; whom I never
But once beheld here in this house yet wish
That he beheld me now and heard me;
You are so like your brother, that methinks I speak to him,
And that provokes a blush to assail my cheek;
He smiles like you, his eyes like you; pray lady
Where is the gentleman? 'twas for his sake
sp.p: I would have lain with you, would it were as lawful to fellow nights with him.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Troth I do wish it.

sp.speaker: Aless.
sp.l: And if in this you enrich me with your counsel, I'll
Be a grateful taker.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Sure my brother
Is blessed in your affection, and shall have
Good time to understand so.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Alesandra

sp.speaker: Aless.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: A word, come quickly.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: O ye heavens! how strangely one hour works upon another. It was but now heartsick, and longed for meat,
sp.l: Which being set before me I abhor.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What frights you thus from your chamber?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Such a fury as thou.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: How now? hast lost thy wits?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I'll swear thou hast, for thou hast candled
Thy sweet but poisonous language to dishonour
Me thy most wretched sister, who no better than a vile
Instrument to thy desires, deserves to be styled,
Bawd, worse than the bawds.
Who every day i'th' week shake hands with hell.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Have patience dearest sister; I protest,
By all the graces that become a man,
I have not wronged Dariene nor her lord.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Thou shalt not then by heaven.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: By all goodness, not
With a well blush discourse fair Alissandra
Supposing me your sister hath discovered
The true pangs of her fancy towards Tibaldo,
And in it craved my aid, which heard, even then,
My brutish purpose broke its neck, and I
Will prove the daughter's husband, that came hither,
A traitor to the mother.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: My noble brother,
Our doings are alike, for by Trebatio
(Whom I with honour name) his father's foulness shall be
Cut off and crossed.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Get to your chamber;
No longer will I play the woman's part,
This night shall change my habit with my heart.

sp.speaker: Nichol.
sp.p: In this chamber she lies, and that's her window would I were in: the air bites, but the bit that I shall bite anon sharpens. my stomach, the watchword is a cornet, (Cornet within) it speaks, she bids me come without a light, and reason sheds light enough herself; wink thou one-eyed bawd, be thou an emblem of thy Mr. and burn in secret.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: What says my most moist-handed sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Who is there with you?

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: No christian creature, I enter solus.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I fear I must entreat you to stay a little.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: As long as thou desirest, but-wilt come down?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: I would be loath to lose all upon rest,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Shall I mount then?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: For mine honour being once cracked.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Crack a pudding: I'll not meddle with thine honour.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Say you should get me with child.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I hope I am not the first lord has got a lady with child.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Is the night hushed?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There's nothing stirring, the very mice are asleep , as I am noble, I'll deal with thee like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I'll do that then, which some citizens will not do, to some lord.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Take your word, I come.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Ud's my life!

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: What's the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: I hear a lute, and sure it comes this way.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My most loved lord, step you aside, I would not have you seen for the saving of my right hand, preserve mine honour, as I preserve your love.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Pox on your cat's guts.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: To an unworthy window, who is thus kind?

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Look out of it, and 'tis the-richest casement
That ever let in air.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Trebatio.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Ay, my most fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Neither of both good sir;
Pray play upon some other, you abuse me,
And that which seems worse, in your father's house.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Brave girl.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: But you are young enough to be forgiven,
If you will mend hereafter, the night has in it
Unwholesome fogs, and blasts; to bed my lord,
Lest they attach your beauty: nothing more,
I'll pay you for your song.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Are you gone so?
Well, you hard-hearted one, you shall not ever
Be lady of yourself — away.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O my lord, I have stood sentinel as you bade me, but I am frighted.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: With what?

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: The nightmare rides you, my lady is conjured up.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Now the devil lay her down, prevented in the very act.

sp.speaker: Carg.
sp.l: She works by magic, and knows all.

sp.speaker: Dari.
sp.l: Do you shrink back my lord? you may with shame;
Have I ta'en you napping my lord?

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: But not with the manner my lady.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Have you no bird to fly at, but what sits on your own son's fist?

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.l: How! my son's fist? (Harlot

sp.speaker: Darie.
sp.l: Yes, the lady whom you wrought to have been your
Your son has long since won to be his bride,
Both they and I have this night exercised
our wits to mock your dotage.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: Am I then gulled?

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.p: Yes my lord, and bulled too, yonder's Tibaldo Neri come this morning.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.l: So early, is his sister with him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not that I saw, but I saw him kiss my young mistress, three or four times, I think 'twere good to ask the banes of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.p: Wilt 'twere no worse, let's in, and give 'em the morning's salutation.

sp.speaker: Dare.
sp.l: I'll tell him all.

sp.speaker: Nicho.
sp.l: Sweet lady, seal my pardon with a kiss,
He never was born, that never did amiss.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Florence, Piero, Pisa, Mutio, Tornelli, Philippe.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Sir, I have found Angelo with long and busy search.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And will he come?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Your honour (As you charged me) I impawned
For his safe passage.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By my life he shall; when will he come?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: My friend brings him along.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Philippo Mutio, go and persuade our daughter
To walk, and take the air.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I'll play that orator.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Attend the Duke of Pisa; prithee Piero
Discover where this Angelo lay lurking.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: The world he has shut up, and now the book
He reads, is only here, see where he comes.
sp.stage: Enter Angelo as a friar, Fyametta.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Way for my daughter; look you, there's Angelo.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Ha? yes, 'tis the star I sail by; hold me not,
Why do you stick like rocks, to bar my way,
And utterly to wrack me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Yes, I am mad, o my best life, my soul!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Whom seek you lady?

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Do you not know me sir?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Dost thou not love me?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: At very heart?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes, at the very soul!

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Burns not your love,
With that most holy fire, the god of marriage
kindles in man and woman?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Ha, no?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He says no.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Then so, quod dedi perdidi.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How can I love you lady?
I have climbed too many of such fruitless trees.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Have you indeed?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes, and have pulled the apples.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Now I beshrew your fingers.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And when I touched 'em, found 'em turned to dust.
Why should you love me? I have changed my pleasure
In beauteous dames, more than I have my dreams,
Four in one night.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He'll prove a lusty Larrence;
This is the star you sail by though.

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.l: Why should you love me? I am but a tomb,
Gay outside, but within, rotten and foul.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I'll swear thou'rt most diseased, even in thy soul;
O thou, thou most perfidious man alive,
So prosper, as my poor sick heart doth thrive;
Give me thy hand, I hate thee, fare-thee-well.
Come, I make thee my heaven, were't once my hell.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I'm rapt above the spheres, joy strikes me dumb.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: T'hast lent unto mine age a score of years,
More than ere nature promised, by thy loving
This noble prince; thou'rt his then?

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: His — to prove it; hence
Thou from me; never more behold mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now find I, that a lover's heart last dies.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ay, ay, so, so; if it die, it shall be buried.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Good reverend sir, stay you, and as you witness
This my divorce, so shall you seal my contract.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: I will, your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fiametta,
Make choice thyself of thine own wedding day.

sp.speaker: Fya.
sp.l: Tomorrow be it, loves poison is delay,
Gallants, pray stir betimes, and rouse your mistresses;
Let some invite lord Vanni and his lady;
We dine today with lord Jacomo,
Thither let's hasten: sir, this holy man,
Shall be this night my confessor; about midnight,
expect my sending for you.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Your devotion
Commands my service. We're least i'th friar's stead.
The prince be your confessor; girl prepare
To play the bride tomorrow, and then being laid,
One night passed o'er think never to rise a maid.
sp.stage: Trumpets sounding services carried covered over the stage, poor attending torrents one, then enter Jacomo bore betwixt the two Dukes, Piero, Philippo, Tornelli, Mutio.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No more of compliment, my lord Gentili;
Such noble welcomes have we had this day,
We must take blushing leaves, cause we can pay
Nothing but thanks.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's more than the whole debt comes to,
Never saw I tables crowned with braver store;
I know no man that spends my nor gives more,
And yet a full sea still: why yonder fellow,
The brave mock-prodigal has spent all indeed,
He that made beggars proud, begs now himself for need.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But who relieves him now? none, for I know
He that in riotous feasting, wastes his store,
Is like a fair tree which in summer bore
Boughs laden till they cracked, with leaves and fruit;
Whose plenty lasting, all men came unto 't;
And plucked and filled their laps and carry away;
But when the boughs grow bare, and leaves decay:
And the great tree stands sapless, withered dry,
Than each one casts on it a scornful eye,
And grieves to see it stand, nay do not grieve,
Albeit the axe down to the root it cleave;
The fall of such a tree, will I beware,
I know both when to spend, and when to spare.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly spoken

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Nay good my lord make haste.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Here's a child lost i'th staying.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Get 2. at night for't.
What is the bride yet dressed?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: She's rigging sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis well, music? from whence?
What chambers that?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: It joins close to the
Lodgings of the bride.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Inquire.
If she be ready, Mutio, say her bridegroom
attends on her below.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: I shall my lord.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Tarry, she looks herself out.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Come, come loiterer;

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Fair welcome to your grace, and to that prince,
That should have been my bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Should ha' been?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Is the moon changed already?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: In her changes the
Moon is constant, man is only varying,
And never in one circle long is tarrying,
But one man in the moon at once appears,
Such praise (Being true to one) a woman bears.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Take thou that praise and to this prince be true,
Come down and marry him.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: What would the world say,
If I should marry two men in one day?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That villain has bewitched her.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Sir what villain?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That slave, the banished runagate.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Cast not on him
Such foul aspersions, till you know his guilt;
Even now you said he was a worthy spirit,
Crowned him with praise, and do you now condemn
An absent man unheard?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll hang thee traitor.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Lock all the gates of Florence, lest he scape.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Our pardon, whosoever takes and kill him.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Oh! who would trust in princes, the vain breath,
Who in a minute gives one man life and death?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Come forth thou threatened man, here kill him all,
Lower than what you stand on . none can fall.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I now must stand your arrows, but you shoot
Against a breast as innocent —

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As a traitor's.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Your patience sir,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Talkest thou of patience? that by thy most perfidious —

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hear me pray.
Or if not me, hear then this reverend man.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What makes that friar there?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Father speak your mind.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: I was enjoined to be her confessor,
And came but then she won me to a vow,
By oath of all my orders, face to face,
to hear her speak unto Angelo, 'twas done,
He came, when falling down on both her knees,
Her eyes drowned all in tears, she opens a book,
Charging him read his oaths and promises,
The contract of their hands, hearts, yea and souls,
And asked if Angelo would marry her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: He looking pale as death, said faintly no.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Faintly, he then was willing?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Pray hear him out.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Thrice tried: he thrice cried no; at which this lady
Desperately snatching from her side two knives,
Had stabbed herself to th'heart, but that we knit
Our force against it, what should I do in this?
Not marry her, or rob her of heaven's bliss?
Which glory had been greater to have ta'en,
A husband from her, or to have seen her slain?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then you have married her?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Brave girl.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I'll cut that knot asunder with my sword.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: The hands which heaven hath joined, no man can part.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: The hands they may, but never shall the heart,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why didst thou make to him thy promise then?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Women are born, but to make fools of men.
She that's made sure to him, she loves not well,
Her banes are asked here, but she weds in hell;
Parents that match their children 'gainst their will,
Teach them not how to live, but how to kill.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Parrot, parrot,
I'll stop your prating, break into her chamber,
And lay the villain bleeding at her feet.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Villain? it is my husband.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Enter and kill him.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Enter, but kill him he that dares, I blush
To see two princes so degenerate

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: O noble brother!

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: What would you have him do?
He well deserves to have her to his wife;
Who gives to you a daughter, her a life,
In sight of angels she to him was given,
so that in striking him, you fight with heaven.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You see there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Troth none;
I threw at all (And gamester's luck) all's gone;
Farewell brave spirited girl, he that 'gainst wind,
Fire and the sea, law and a woman's mind,
Strives, is a fool, that's I, I'll now be wise,
And never more put trust in woman's eyes.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: I love thee for that word withal my heart.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Will you come down pray?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Swear as you are a Duke.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yet more ado .

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Will you not trust your father?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Why should I? you see there is no trust i'th' daughter;
Swear by your hopes of good you will not touch
His nail to hurt him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By my hopes I swear.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: And you too?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes, what's falling none can rear.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: We come then noble friend, flag not thy wings,
In this war I defy a camp of Kings.
sp.stage: Enter Nicolletto, Tibaldo, Alphonsin. Daariene, Alissand, Trebatio.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: See, see, more shoals of friends, most beauteous ladies,
Fair welcomes to you all.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: My lord those tides,
Are turned, these ladies are transformed to brides.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: We heard the happy news, and therefore sent,
To marry joys with joys, yours, with our own,
Yours (I see) prosper, ours are overthrown.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: How mean you overthrown?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Your own eyes shall be witness how: nay, nay, pray rise,
I know your heart is up, though your knees down.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: All that we stand in fear of is your frown.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: And all dear father which I beg of you,
Is that you love this man but as I do.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What beg you of this prince?

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: That he would take
One favour from me, which myself shall make.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Pray let it be of willow.

sp.speaker: Fia.
sp.l: Well then it shall.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why willow? is the noble prince forsaken?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: All women's faults, one for another taken,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Now in good sooth my lord, she has but used you
As watermen use their fares, for she looked one way,
And rowed another, you but wore her glove,
The hand was Angelo's, and she dealt wisely.
Let woman never love man, or if she do,
Let him never know it, make him write, wait woe,
Court, cog, and curse, and swear, and lie, and pine,
Till love bring him to death's door, else he's not mine,
That flesh eats sweetest that's picked close to th' bone,
Water drinks best, that's hewed even from the stone;
Men must be put to 't home.

sp.speaker: Nico.
sp.l: He that loves ducking, let him come learn of thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: She has good skill;
At table will we hear a full discourse
Of all these changes, and these marriages,
Both how they shuffled, cut, and dealt about,
What cards are best, after the trumps were out,
Who played false play, who true, who sought to save
An ace ith' bottom, and turned up a knave;
For love is but a card-play, and all's lost,
Unless you cog, he that packs best, wins must,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Since such good gamesters are together met,
As you like this, we'll play another set.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
